messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] anyone care to Kantei this :-)
messages.msgSnippet: Rich  et al- The design is too modern to be a fighting tsuba in my opinion, so it has to be Edo period, the gold chasing is a bit roughly done to my eye,
messages.messageBody:
Rich et al-
The design is too "modern" to be a fighting tsuba in my opinion, so
it has to be Edo period, the gold chasing is a bit roughly done to my
eye, which either means later work or lesser skill. I think later,
like 1750 on and some school outside Edo as this was likely on the
sword of someone more concerned with fashion. If I knew any schools
I'd name one but...
-t

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: Kantei Tsuba #2
messages.msgSnippet: I vote for Yagyu.  Melted surface; (how should I put it?) perfunctory modelling of a not-very-complex motif which looks Yagyu-ish; small size; thick; rim
messages.messageBody:
I vote for Yagyu. Melted surface; (how should I put it?) perfunctory modelling of a not-very-complex motif which looks Yagyu-ish; small size; thick; rim larger than seppa dai; brown color.

David Zincavage

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Kantei Tsuba #2
messages.msgSnippet: Hi Jim - Interesting kantei #2 tsuba. Could this fall into Yagyu or possibly Hoan work? Resembles Kanayama but with that linear bone and lack of other knobby
messages.messageBody:
Hi Jim -

Interesting kantei #2 tsuba. Could this fall into Yagyu or possibly Hoan work? Resembles Kanayama but with that linear bone and lack of other "knobby" bones, I would look more to Yagyu (but it lacks the "peak" in its shape") or Hoan. I'm not very familiar with Hoan though.

Ron
STL
----- Original Message -----
From: Jim Gilbert
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Tuesday, March 07, 2006 12:57 PM

messages.subject: Kantei Tsuba #2 - my bid
messages.msgSnippet: Hi Jim, excellent, and that was fast :-) ok, here is my bid for Kantei #2 ONO Sukashi The first thing that struck me was the very bold design, the heavy set
messages.messageBody:
Hi Jim, excellent, and that was fast :-)

ok, here is my bid for Kantei #2

ONO Sukashi

The first thing that struck me was the very bold design, the heavy set
sukashi work. Next, the squareness of the sukashi cut, much like Akasaka
work where the walls of the Sukashi are very straight. As for the iron
itself, it has a somewhat soft look to it, and the thickness is typical
of this group as is the Maru Gata. I have found no reference to tekkotsu
in this group yet so I cannot make a judgement on that either way. All
these things lead me to my judgement of ONO.

When I first looked at this tsuba, both Ono and Yagyu popped into my
mind. One thing I found when looking into this group is that they based
there work style on both Yagyu and Kanayama styles.

Kind regards

Rich Turner


--
*Richard Turner - Nihonto Message Board*
/for the discussion of all things Nihonto./
www.nihontomessageboard.com <http://www.nihontomessageboard.com/nmb/>
